title: B2 Vocabulary - Emotions & Collocations
subject: english
description: Upper-intermediate vocabulary covering emotions, personality traits, and common adjective-noun or verb-noun collocations.

questions.text: She was absolutely _____ when she heard the good news.
questions.explanation: 'Thrilled' is a strong B2 adjective meaning extremely happy or excited.

questions.text: I was _____ with the service at the restaurant; it was terrible.
questions.explanation: 'Dissatisfied' is the specific adjective for not being happy with quality or service.

questions.text: He is very _____; he never changes his mind once he's decided.
questions.explanation: 'Stubborn' describes someone who refuses to change their opinion or chosen course of action.

questions.text: Could you _____ me a favor and post this letter?
questions.explanation: Collocation: You 'do' someone a favor.

questions.text: I'm really _____ on learning Spanish this year.
questions.explanation: 'Keen on' is a common structure. 'Interested' takes 'in', 'fond' takes 'of'.

questions.text: It was a _____ risk, but it paid off in the end.
questions.explanation: A 'calculated risk' is a chance taken after careful estimation of the probable outcome.

questions.text: She is totally _____ to her family; she would do anything for them.
questions.explanation: 'Devoted' means very loving or loyal.

questions.text: I am _____ up with this rain! It's been raining for days.
questions.explanation: 'Fed up with' means annoyed or bored by something that you have experienced for too long.

questions.text: Please _____ attention to what I am saying.
questions.explanation: Collocation: You 'pay attention' to something.

questions.text: He was _____ when he saw the spider on his bed.
questions.explanation: 'Terrified' means very scared. 'Afraid' is less strong and not usually used alone for extreme fear without modifiers.

questions.text: It's important to be _____ and check the facts before posting online.
questions.explanation: 'Responsible' means behaving properly and sensibly.

questions.text: Don't lose your _____; stay calm!
questions.explanation: Collocation: To 'lose your temper' means to get angry.

questions.text: She felt _____ when she realized she had forgotten his birthday.
questions.explanation: 'Guilty' describes the feeling of having done something wrong.

questions.text: You need to _____ a decision soon.
questions.explanation: Collocation: You 'make' a decision.

questions.text: He is very _____; you can always trust him to do what he says.
questions.explanation: 'Reliable' means consistently good in quality or performance; able to be trusted.

questions.text: I'm extremely _____ about the interview tomorrow.
questions.explanation: 'Anxious' means feeling worried, nervous, or uneasy.

questions.text: It was very _____ of you to help that old lady.
questions.explanation: 'Thoughtful' means showing consideration for the needs of other people.

questions.text: He has a tendency to _____ his promises.
questions.explanation: Collocation: You 'break a promise' (or 'keep a promise').

questions.text: Be _____! We don't have all day.
questions.explanation: 'Reasonable' means having sound judgment; fair and sensible.

questions.text: She is very _____ to criticism.
questions.explanation: 'Sensitive' means easily upset by the things people say or do. ('Sensible' means practical).
